Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: The station is set to lock its doors in ten minutes.
Story: The shrill wail of the evacuation alarm slices through the clatter of the construction site, and I freeze, hammer in hand. My foreman’s voice booms, “Drop everything! Muster point, now!” I know the drill—no exceptions, no delays. But my phone buzzes in my pocket, a reminder that the polling station closes in ten minutes. I’d promised myself I’d vote this year, that I’d make my voice count. The station is just down the street, but if I leave the site without checking in at the muster point, I’ll be breaking protocol, risking my job and the trust of my crew. My heart pounds as I glance at the exit, then at the gathering workers. The weight of responsibility presses on me from both sides—my duty to my team, and my duty as a citizen. I can’t be in two places at once, but both roles demand I act now. My hands tremble as I try to decide which expectation I’ll have to let down.
